I learned I was dyslexic while researching the topic to determine if my daughter was dyslexic (she is). I struggled to read until I was 21 years old. I remember the book I was reading when it occurred to me that I wasn't struggling to read. It was John Kenneth Galbraith's "The Affluent Society" assigned by a wonderful professor I had for US Economic History. I always loved learning and found my own ways to tackle text without actually having to read all the words. However, once I crossed that threshold and became a skilled reader I continued to read more and more. What I think got me over the threshold from struggling to skilled dyslexic reader, was that I had, over time, visually memorized enough words that I could read fluently. It has been a real gift because there is so much wisdom and enjoyment in text.

Dyslexia is different for my daughter than it is for me. For me, reading was the struggle. For her, getting the words to come out the way she wants, either orally or in writing, is the struggle. We live in a read/write/talk world, particularly in school. I'm still not sure how to help this bright child of mine get through a school system that insists on read/write/talk as the primary and sometimes only valid learning system. I don’t think the school system does either. So much has been learned about dyslexia in the past 10 years - it just hasn't made it to the class room. I'd like to change that.

This column suggests an interesting thesis: that conventions produce more centrist candidates than do primaries. I agree that backroom deal-making tended to produce national tickets that embraced the center. As well, primaries tend to attract more partisan voters, which might result in more partisan candidacies in some instances. But recent presidential primaries seem to have consistently produced fairly centrist candidates: on the Democratic side, Clinton, Gore, Kerry and Obama; on the Republican side Dole, Bush 43, McCain and Romney.

I'd enjoy learning more about what political scientists have to say on this question.

I studied Latin in high school. It was my favorite subject. As a tenth grader, I represented my school in a city-wide (Baltimore) “Latin contest” competing with twelfth graders. Later, at UCLA, I majored in Mandarin, adding Japanese and Tibetan. In graduate school, however, I became interested in Coptic and Middle Egyptian (hieroglyphics). As Coptic was taught in the Religious Studies Department, I was required, altogether unreasonably, to study a year of Greek before I would be accepted for Coptic. Then I got interested in the history of Christianity and religions of the Hellenistic era, so continued with Greek. Spent two years in Israel studying Coptic, Middle Egyptian and of course a whole lot of Hebrew, modern and Biblical. All this aside from the French and German one has to learn to pass the GRE exams.
So I know something about how UNhelpful Latin is for learning any other language or improving one’s knowledge of English. There is no reason to learn Latin unless you want to become proficient in medieval European history, in which case you must also learn medieval French and Greek of the later Byzantine period, or if you want to become a Catholic priest and go for an advanced degree in Canon Law. I am a Catholic, and if the Church reverts to the Latin Mass I will join some other church. Period. The Church is in the grip of ultra-conservatives, and nothing good can come of it.

We also know that Regan era's "trickle down" economy did NOT work. Where are the jobs after GWB's own 8 years of trickle-down?

Funny how this piece makes no mention at all of the best V.P. of the past 50 years: Al Gore.  The man who should have been president did not get that opportunity essentially because he lost the black vote (i.e., a few hundred black Americans in Florida who didn't get to vote at all while one black American in Washington got to vote twice).  In any case, the very real accomplishments of the Clinton administration can be credited at least as much to Mr. Gore as they can to Mr. Clinton.  The fact that he was untouched by the President's proclivity to tempt the fates by inviting personal scandal didn't help him to avoid the problem of guilt by association.  Even so, he deserves to be remembered with fondness and admiration.  Had he not been robbed of his election victory in 2000, we would undoubtedly be well on our way to energy independence by now.
